turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Harvey Lyle Entsminger, petitioner versus Iowa.
Mr. Belin, you may proceed with your argument.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Honorable Chief Justice and Associate Justices, may it please the Court.
The basic issue in this case is what constitutes effective assistance of counsel.
The case is on appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa, and involves the issues of due process and equal protection of the laws and effective assistance of counsel.
The petitioner Harvey Entsminger was arrested without warrant on June the 12th, 1964 on a traffic violation.

At the time of his arrest the Des Moines Police Apartment were looking for Mr. Entsminger on an alleged bad check charge and he was taken to the police station and arrested and asked to leave his personal effects with the jailer for safekeeping as was customary at the Des Moines police station.
Included in these personal effects which were placed in a locker in a safe were two handwritten personal letters written by the petitioner.

Two-and-a-half weeks after his arrest, Lieutenant Dawson of the Identification Bureau of the Des Moines police department asked the petitioner to submit a sample of his handwriting and the petitioner refused.
Lieutenant Dawson had been present at the arrest two-and-a-half weeks earlier.

He remembered that there were two letters that have been placed in the safe and although of these were not instrumentalities of any crime or evidence of any crime, he removed these letters from the safe.
Now there's a dispute in the record as to whether or not this was voluntary or not voluntary.
In any event, several months later, in October with court-appointed counsel, the indigent Harvey Enstminger was tried for the bad check charge.
These letters were used as an important part of the chain of evidence.
Mr. Entsminger was convicted.
He was sentenced to a term not to exceed 10 years and he is now incarcerated in the Fort Madison Penitentiary in Iowa.

Mr. Enstminger asked the court to appoint a new lawyer to represent him to file a motion for a new trial and to file an appeal to the Iowa Supreme Court and in the State of Iowa appeal as a matter of right, a new counsel was appointed, a man by the name of Henry Warnley.
He filed a motion for a new trial, and the motion was overruled and the sentence imposed.
Then Mr. Warnley had 60 days to file on behalf of the petitioner a notice of appeal, and within this 60-day period, a notice was filed.
And that gave Mr. Warnley 90 days to file what we call a printed record on appeal.
Unfortunately, at the end of February, the 90-day period expired, there was no record on appeal filed.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The printed, the printed record is the full record --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: The full record, yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- including any of the testimony that --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- is relevant.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, Justice White.
It's --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Isn't the counsel, doesn't the Attorney General pretty much concede this part of your case?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now on page, for example, on page 28 of his brief, as well as elsewhere, it seems to me that he suggests that you are entitled to have the case remanded to the Iowa Supreme Court because of the inaction of court-appointed counsel and have the case remanded for carrying the appeal on the basis of the record.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, Justice Fortas

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, where does that leave us?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: I think that basically, this is the primary relief that we are seeking here although we do raise the additional issue as to whether or not there is a sufficient record before this Court.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Sufficient what?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Sufficient record before this Court because the actual trial transcript has been introduced as an exhibit filed with the record on appeal.
Whether or not there is sufficient record before this Court because of the basis of the seizure without warrant of these personal communication.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes, but the real question, the question then the only remaining question that I see as subject here enlightened -- enlightening me is whether we ought to reach the search and seizure question?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Or whether we just ought to remand as the Attorney General if I correctly understand his brief suggests that Iowa Supreme Court for the consideration of the appeal.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Am I -- am I right in --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, you're absolutely right, Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Was that --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: That the Attorney -- the Attorney General as a matter of fact in this particular case, the appointed counsel Mr. Warnley finally did serve, after the expiration of this 90-day period, Mr. Warnley did served a notice on the Attorney General specifying his intent to file a record and a brief and although the Iowa Supreme Court had ordered that the case be submitted on a clerk's transcript which is not a transcript of the record at all, that the Iowa Supreme Court set aside that order without prejudice to the Attorney General's office to file a motion to dismiss and I think it's indicative of the Attorney General's office that they did not elect to stand on the technicality of a motion to dismiss, but rather wanted to have the appeal heard in substance.

And in this particular case, they are not arguing about sending it down to the Iowa Supreme Court although I think there might be some disagreement between us as to whether or not on the one hand, we argue, at least I argue, that the clerk's transcript system itself is either per se unconstitutional because it permits this very thing happening that happened here, and by the way, I personally have taken a survey of the clerk's transcript cases over the past 15 years in Iowa and out of several hundred cases, there has never been a reversal, at least to the best of my knowledge.

And so, I argue that either the clerk's transcript system itself is per se unconstitutional or in the alternative it cannot be used under Douglas, and as reaffirmed this recently as your decision on Mundy, the Missouri case that it cannot be used without some protection of the right for indigent defendants.
And so I say there would be not basic issue before we reached the final issue of whether or not we have --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I may --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: - the case occurred here.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I may be wrong about this, but my reading of the -- my recollection of the Attorney General's brief is that at least state is agreeable having this case remanded to the Iowa courts for consideration of the appeal on the basis of a complete record and with the newly appointed counsel.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So, if that so, I don't see what we've got left here --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Well (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you mean --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I would -- I would be interested in knowing whether or not the clerk's transcript system that you call it, is something that is used regularly by lawyers who have examined the record and have decided on their own that there is nothing really to appeal here.
Or whether or not -- or whether from the contrary in this case counsel simply neglected the work.

I think if a paid counsel sometimes, the paid counsel – we have had cases here or at least request to take cases in which the counsel simply has neglected to take the necessary steps within the required time.

And then the -- the defendant who doesn't get his appeal asks for habeas corpus or something else to let -- to make the state give him -- giving him an appeal and know it was -- it's neglected his counsel, his own hired counsel.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is -- what is it in this case?
Is this the way that the Iowa lawyer, appointed lawyer used to -- to -- to let the court know we don't think if there's any merit in the case or do they just not do the work or what?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Your Honor, I think it happens in both instances.

In this particular case for instance, the -- I think the thing that perhaps instigated the late filing of this notice of intent to file the record was a letter from the petitioner to the court appointed attorney and the court appointed attorney wrote back that your case was appealed and as soon as I receive the record, this letter was a letter written on March 9.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If I may --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: -- they've got to do something when they received the record the transcript in December already.
Then later in October of the year, he writes to the petitioner because the petitioner has meanwhile a petition for certiorari to the Iowa Supreme Court which was overruled as being untimely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: He says, that on the basis of my examination of the record, I don't think you have any basis for appeal or in substance this is what he says.
Now I don't know whether or not it was his inadvertence --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: -- or whether or not he really felt that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh you mean, there's -- the record does contain some expression by him that -- that there's no merit.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Well, this is a very late expression.
It's about several weeks before the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What would you say the rule should be?
Is there a constitutional rule?
Let's assume that this man had hired his own counsel?
And his own counsel, instead of taking appeal, then he just didn't do it.
What would you -- would you say that it's a constitutional rule that the defendant has -- may have an appeal anyway?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Your Honor, I think the basic constitutional issues is whether or not the clerk's transcript system can be used as a vehicle by court-appointed counsel because I don't think would happen --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes but that's not my question.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: In your -- in your situation, I don't think there would be any basis for appeal because I don't see any equal protection argument.
Now if there was --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: -- outright --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- what if, but do you think there should be a constitutional rule if appointed counsel makes this same error?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Well, I think that the -- that the dangers are far greater in court appointed counsel doing this because of laziness or inadvertence, whereas I think that the retained counsel is not going let this happen, at least I don't think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I guess it happens all the time?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: It does happen, but I don't think the degree is nearly as great.

I think that -- I would say this and this is a practical matter, I think that often, a clerk's transcript appeal is used where there are perhaps might not be any basis for appeal because it gives a delay of several months within which the defendant might be able to place as [Voice Overlap]

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the -- but the appointed counsel, the defendant with hired counsel who haven't -- the hired counsel went through the same procedure, would have received exactly the same treatment as the Supreme Court, wouldn't he?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, if this were a conscientious effort to do it.
As I don't happen to think it was in the Enstminger case and I don't happen to think it is in the great majority of indigent cases.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What do you mean?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: I think that the likelihood of a -- of a retained lawyer through neglect letting a clerk's transcript system arise is much less than the likelihood of a court-appointed lawyer.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think this makes a constitutional difference?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: I think it makes a constitutional difference to the extent that if the man could have retained a lawyer, I don't think it would have happened nearly as much as it might have happened in the other situation, yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose if -- if the retained lawyer took the money and then did nothing for him and his counsel, I mean, his client had wanted him to do so, he'd be subject to discipline, wouldn't he, by the -- by the Bar for having neglected his professional duty?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.
I happen to think that perhaps this should happen in -- in appointed counsel cases also --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: -- but again, you have -- it's a question of judgment.

I think the only issue really is whether or not you're going to leave it in the hands of one lawyer to make the determination of whether or not there is merit and I think that we would -- at least I would submit that I think the lawyer is going to make a better calculated decision if he's actually on a retainer as opposed to a situation where you might look on this as a burden upon this time because he's accepting the duty.
I mean, he theoretically shouldn't but yes, as a practical matter, I think the situation does arise.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, in Iowa -- the -- by the transcript system, the Iowa Court never gets around looking at the printed record or anything?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: No.
And --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Never passes on anything that was raised on the motion for new trial?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: That's correct, and as a matter of fact, the tragedy here was that there actually was a full transcript of the trial court record available at the time it went up on the clerk, – at the time the Iowa Supreme Court ordered it to submit on the clerk's transcript.
But the clerk's transcript does not require imprinted abstract of record at all and so we have the error in Douglas compounded because in Douglas, at least there was a record on appeal.
In this case, there is no record on appeal and that's why I really argue in essence that the system itself is per se unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But is it one step beyond the California as we heard about yesterday?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes sir.
Yes, Your Honor.

In other words, if -- the reason that I argue that this -- that the clerk's transcript system is really per se unconstitutional is that I don't think you ought to have an appeal in form that's totally void of substance.
That's totally void of a record on appeal apart from totally void of a brief and argument.

And even if it's a conscious decision on the part of counsel whether he be retained or appointed counsel, I don't think we want to have a judiciary system where we have this sub rows of form of appeal.

I'd like to save the rest of this time for any rebuttal although I think there's going to be too much to rebut because I think both the Attorney General's office and at least I feel that in this particular instance that the petitioner's constitutional rights were violated, there is a question of what to do with the clerk's transcript system itself.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Bennett.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, members of the Court.
I'm going to be very brief this morning because as Mr. Justice Fortas has already pointed out, we more or less conceded the case insofar as a remand being necessary.
I would give you just a little background.
I think you would be interested in the background as to why the Attorney General would be willing to come into Court -- into this Court and confess error on the case.
And in fact I would have supposed I wouldn't even be here today but for the fact that the petitioner has raised the question of the underlying merits.
I went from the Department of Justice here in town to work for Van Nuys, Lawrence Scalise who is no longer Attorney General of Iowa.
And he had brought me in to handle criminal -- criminal appeals and I recall that the first conference we had was about editorials that were being written regarding the clerk's transcript system.

The writer of these editorials is a resident of Des Moines and writes for the Des Moines registrant tribunal and he had been suggesting that the clerk's transcript appeal system was used by some attorneys to -- some attorneys to give the appearance of their appointed or the client for which they were appointed actually getting appeal and the client not getting such an appeal and there was some evidence to this effect.
But anyway, the Attorney General asked me if I would do some research into it and try to come up with some conclusions and some recommendations.

As things worked out, I never had the time to do that research because of the pressing number of appeals and never got into the problem until this Court granted certiorari in the Enstminger case and it's obvious that in the instant case, the petitioner did desire an appeal as was expressed in the record and as you will find in our brief, and I don't think we can say we will relinquish the desire to have plenary review the merits of the proceedings culminating any his conviction and he didn't receive it.
I concede to you in all candor that clerk's transcript does not present an adequate record upon which an individual can obtain meaningful review.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In this case?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: In this case.
I have suggested in the brief that there may be cases in which a reversal could occur because of review of the clerk's transcript.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because of the insufficiency of the indictment or something like that?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Or the Griffin versus California error where the instructions are part of the clerk's transcript --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The instructions are --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: -- and the Court -- yes and the Court has charged the jury relative to the defendant Enstminger to take witness stand.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For what?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That should result on reversal?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: As a matter of question of law?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, what does the clerk's transcript consist?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, there's -- unfortunately, there is no uniformity among the various clerks in the state but, by and large, you can expect to find a copy of either the indictment or the information.
Iowa uses both systems.

A copy of the arraignment, a copy of the -- the arraignment or plea, probably a copy of the verdict, the sentence, most often but not always, the charge to the jury and in this particular case, the clerk's transcript also contained a copy of the motion for a new trial raising the various constitutional issues.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So there might be cases as Justice Douglas suggests where the questions is one of law and not at all as to insufficiency of the evidence or rulings on admission of evidence or anything but simply the sufficiency of the indictment or the instructions to the jury as to what the content of the particular offense was or -- where a clerk's transcript would be adequate?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, that's correct Your Honor except -- I appreciate that whenever clerk's transcript is used for a review there is no argument.
It's not an adversary proceeding at all.
It's simply is the court reviewing the clerk's transcript.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: What happens is the -- the printed record, this is an abstract of the record, it's not usually the full trial record and the trial transcript.
The -- oh, I lost my thought early -- the idea was trying to put across --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So there is no argument?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I don't quite follow that because you think that there might be cases where a perfectly -- a perfectly careful lawyer might have one good solid point on appeal which could be fully disclosed and exposed by a clerk's transcript and therefore he wouldn't bother asking for anything else and then he'd go and argue his case and probably win it if let's say there were instructions and violation of Griffin against California.
Now what would be --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: And this is very conceivable.
In my months in the office, this has not happened.
The clerk's transcript system has been utilized only where the court reviews it itself and there is no --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Without any -- without any --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- argument?
Or without any briefing, I guess.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No briefing here?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: No briefing, no record, just the clerk's transcript.
Now this is equivalent by the way to what his Court has spoken off in Griffin versus Illinois.
If you -- I think check at Footnote 2 at that opinion, the mandatory record referred to in that case is very similar to the clerk's transcript in our case or in the case of Iowa.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in the -- in this case, the state did appoint counsel to represent him on appeal?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Didn't they?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes.
And this case --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the sole -- the state furnished him counsel and the counsel either decided this to submit it on the clerk's transcript because he didn't see any merit in it or simply neglected to proceed with the appeal which he's told this company or his client that he was proceeding with.
Is there any indication in this record which it was?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: I would say that the indications in the record probably go to more of the -- more of neglect of some sort rather than counsel having come to a conclusion that the appeal was frivolous.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well then --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Because counsel had written the petitioner on two different occasions; once in March and once again in September indicating that a -- that a brief or a record would be filed.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would you say -- or would -- you would suggest then that the constitutional rule in appointed cases, in appointed cases, the -- the appeal would not be disposed of for any reason without a full record in the appearance of counsel.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: No, I wouldn't suggest that if I follow your question --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what I -- what I wonder is that why do you think the defendant should not be charged with the error or neglect of his counsel, like he might well be if the counsel was retained?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: In this given -- in this case?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, yes?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Now -- well, in the first place, I am not certain.
You -- you addressed the same question to Mr. Belin.
I am not certain that if -- if retained counsel did nothing without the knowledge of his client --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: – and his client received a clerk's transcript appeal that you wouldn't have a constitutional problem there.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's -- that really what I am --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: I suppose (Voice Overlap) you could express it -- you could express that in -- in terms of ineffective assistance of counsel or something of that akin and this would entitle that individual to relief.
In this case, we have something that -- I have a record here or we have a record, it's not of our making and we have something in this case that goes a step further than that.
The court was apprised by the petitioner several days prior to the time that they affirmed his conviction on the clerk's transcripts.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would you think the rule as saying that the both appointive and hired counsel -- what is unconstitutional there?
Same reason, different lawyer, equal protection.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: In the case of a retained counsel?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you say that it's a constitutional should be the same, what is -- what is the constitutional error if -- if they affirm on a clerk's transcript.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, in the case of the indigent --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: -- because if you say that they used the clerk's transcript on which to affirm in both -- in both the appointed case and in the retained case, you say that -- that's that -- that's wrong.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, in the case --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) why is it wrong?
What's the constitutional violation?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: In the case of the indigent, and in keeping with this Court's decisions starting with Griffin versus Illinois, right on down to the one that the Court decided, I understand a week or a few days ago, you could spell out the constitutional violation where the Indigent is concerned by State stating that he has not received adequate and full plenary review to which he is entitled and the reason he hasn't received it is because he wasn't able to fire an attorney.
Had he been able to hire an attorney, he could have kept some control over his attorney.
Mr. Enstminger could have -- in checking up now you say you're going to get the brief and where is the brief?
Now in the case of the retained attorney, I suppose you could -- I could only say ineffective assistance of counsel, perhaps you could use the Sixth Amendment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So really -- that's a -- so, are you conceding in this case a constitutional violation of Equal Protection or of the Sixth Amendment?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: This question has bothered me and one that I haven't really come to resolve myself, but I do believe that under this record we would have to concede that this indigent was not or did not obtain whole and effective appellate review to which he was entitled and that within this Court's decisions, he wouldn't be entitled to relief for that reason.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And yet make the same concession if on the same facts retained counsel did the same thing?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, I -- I'm willing to state for the sake of argument that I believe I would make the concession that there would be a constitutional violation if he did nothing and that his client -- and didn't let his client know of anything.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Prior on subject like this as to the first absent the [Inaudible] transcript of the trial, and entered in the [Inaudible] as to the [Inaudible] available and the Court ordered complete transcripts as of --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: The court ordered a complete transcripts Mr. Justice Harlan before the clerk's transcripts was ever filed?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: At the time of the hearing on the motion for new trial, and at the date of sentencing, the petitioner said he wanted to take an appeal.

Counsel had been appointed to help on the new trial, he was requested to stay and assist him in connection with the appeal and the counsel said it was alright, where upon the court said, “I'm appointing this counsel to assist you on appeal and directing that a free transcript be ordered for you.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The full transcript?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: The full transcript, that's his transcript right here, you have it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) and the [Inaudible] to this Court?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: It was --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The lawyer is not [Inaudible] and it was considered done, it wouldn't had available as to the complete review --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: It was mostly the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- the full transcript --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: -- mostly the fault of the lawyer, yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, are there any problems in it?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: I cannot -- in all fairness, I must say that the record shows there was some fault on behalf of the Court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What was that?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: The Court was advised by what the petitioner denominated, a petition for writ of certiorari, advised some eleven or 12 days before they ultimately affirmed the conviction on a clerk's transcript, advised in this pleading that he was not happy with -- with the way that counsel was proceeding with this appeal.
And so in this case, we have a record which goes a little beyond counsel's inaction.

We have a record showing that the Iowa Court was advised that the fact that the petitioner was complaining about the way the appeal went, nonetheless, it was affirmed on the clerk's transcript a few days later.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was that the state action you --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you -- would you -- would you charge the state with the -- with the neglect of any appointed counsel because he was appointed?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: No, Your Honor, but to the extent that the clerk's transcript system allows the counsel appointed to represent indigents to do nothing and to the extent that the ultimate per curium opinion leads those indigents into believe that they've got -- leads the indigents in to believing that they've got a full appeal, then there is something wrong with the system.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Would you say that matter conflicts [Inaudible] clerk's transcript system in there?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: No, I'm not -- I'm not ready to say that as a blanket statement for all cases.

Every lawyer that -- who handles any criminal appeals at all in Iowa knows that the clerk's transcript is quite often used as a delaying tactic, a time to let the man put his orders in affair or put his affairs and order.
It's also occasionally used where an attorney has reviewed the record, felt that any appeal would be frivolous, goes to his client and advises his client at this sits down and talks about it.
The client agrees with the counsel and so he let's go on the clerk's transcript.
So there are situations in which the clerk's transcript is certainly being utilized without there being any -- any suggestion of the constitutional taint to its use.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's sort of an abandonment without an appeal, wasn't that what it amounts to but -- but the device it does give the appellant a little more time out of jail?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That's correct.

We have suggested to the Iowa Court and some proposed rule changes which they have told us they will consider and which are incorporated in the appendix of our brief that they ought to do way with the clerk's transcript appeal, that what they should do is to dismiss the appeal with prejudice if the record or the briefs are not filed on time or with any -- or with any enlargement of time.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Your point here as I understand it is that in this particular case, the court-appointed counsel for the petitioner, that the counsel didn't do his job that the petitioner called that fact to the court's attention that the court ignored that and went ahead and decided this case on the basis of the clerk's transcript and that this amounts to a denial of the right of appeal.
Am I right in this statement?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That's substantially it.
I -- I would, Mr. Justice Fortas, I would like in all fairness to the Court, to the Iowa Court to say that -- that they did not ignore that notice.

This is a situation I -- I realize this is not important where this record is concerned but as a practical matter, I want to tell you about the situation where they simply got more work and they can keep up with and as one hand doing what the other doesn't know.
So this petition for writ of certiorari not being proper and informed was summarily denied without even being aware that Harvey Lyle Enstminger was also some place else.
But of course we're stuck with the record as it shows.

Now, to proceed this a step further, we've asked the Iowa Court in connection with these proposed rule changes that they spell out, what we -- what we think or what this Court might hold to be the obligation of counsel, to spell it out in black and white and tell the attorneys of the State of Iowa what is expected of them whenever they are appointed to represent an indigent and I think that's necessary because in my limited experience I have seen some abuse and this is not been the only case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Were you -- are you making the same statements up here if the Court had -- had not decided the appeal, but it just dismissed it on these facts?
Though he didn't get his appeal and then -- and for the same reasons --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: You would have the same problem, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: But I don't think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And I suppose you would -- I suppose you wouldn't --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: I don't think you would have the problem Mr. Justice White, of the -- of the clerk's transcript system allowing this (Voice Overlap) quite so readily as where you would --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is the appointed counsel compensated in your -- in Iowa?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes, I point out in my brief that counsel -- the appointed counsel is not expected to gratuitously serve.
They are not paid as well as retained lawyers are obviously, but they do get a reasonable compensation, and that varies from court to court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's a bit --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: They are appointed by the District Courts.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Certainly, they're under this clerk's transcript system, every lawyer paid for doing nothing at all?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: I don't know whether they ever be in a situation like there or not Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What do you think the effect of this Court [Inaudible] of your recommendations would be suppose this is [Inaudible] Do you think it's going to be [Inaudible] I suppose, this Court [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Mr. Justice Harlan, I assume the Iowa Court will not act upon the proposed rule changes until such time as this Court has decided not only in the Enstminger case but also the California case that was acted upon yesterday.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Yesterday, oh.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: And I'm sure that whatever guidelines are there might go a long way toward -- they're accepting some proposal like we have filed with the Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think of -- you talked about the clerk's trans -- transcript system, but in this case, in this case, from your argument, the facts are that you have appointed counsel who -- who neglected this to carry through on the appeal.
And we say this is a constitutional error or you -- do you -- do you suggest that's it's a constitutional error when the appointed counsel neglects to do his job?
And that [Inaudible] about it --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, I know that -- I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or at least have come --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: I can't come before (Voice Overlap) I can't come before this Court and say that Mr. Enstminger wasn't treated better than was Douglas or was Brown I guess it was, in Lane versus Brown.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I agree with you in net effect, but -- but you -- I guess you say that the -- the -- at least it's an error when the court knows -- when the court knows that the counsel is being ineffective?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: I think that's right.
I think -- I think it's an error in either case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: But I think -- simply boils down to what constitutional proposition you're going to pin it to.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What -- what is the for hired counsel [Inaudible] that you are [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, I think on this record, you get to find the same -- I think on this record, you've got to find the same type of constitutional defect that you found in Lane versus Brown for the relatively unanimous court.
This case is not at all -- unlike Lane versus Brown.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but that's a -- that was a transcript -- was that a transcript --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That was a transcript problem.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the -- that was Indiana?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That was Indiana.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But that was equal protection?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, I don't know that all the scholars are in agreement as to just exactly whether it was equal protection or due process, but one of the two.
Lane versus Brown involved a situation where a public defender refused to obtain a transcript so that Mr. Brown, I think, it was could take his appeal.
The transcript was a jurisdictional prerequisite to the appeal, to the Indiana Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The defender is not in this -- this case?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: No, it is not this case exactly.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: This is the transcript, the full transcript of [Inaudible] on about this Court, whether it was this case --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: A full transcript --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: [Inaudible] or something else for the [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: The full transcript was made available by the trial court.
The Iowa Supreme Court had nothing to do with that.
They never saw it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Yes, I know but as far as [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- there is no block in his record getting the full transcript?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That's right.
He had --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And I ask you again, what is the precise constitutional ruling --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, under the facts -- under the facts and circumstances in this case, I would still have to comeback and say that it would have to be a denial -- that the indigent was denied full and effective appellate review and I suppose we're talking about either an equal protection or due process problem if it were simply negligence or neglect on it behalf of the counsel, then I suppose we're talking about an ineffective assistance of the counsel which is still a due process proposition as I understand it.
Frankly, we are now --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You are now --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Frankly, I'm floundering a little bit because I haven't given this.
I tried to tie it down to some specific phase.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) we, we -- we have to make a rule for this kind that are constitutional rule, to put [Inaudible] matter but have some importance as to whether [Inaudible] have a reason, but perhaps you might not [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Harlan, I would say this that -- I think it's clear that this man, an indigent designed an appeal from his conviction had the right to full plenary review of the proceedings culminating in that conviction.
Now, this he didn't get.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: He would have had it except for this negligence of his counsel?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, except for the neglect of his counsel apparently and to that extent, he was denied due process.
He wasn't -- he wasn't given the type of appeal to which he wan entitled as a matter of due process.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Now are you saying that we should rule with the constitution as a matter that the man fails to get review because of negligence and proper conduct of his counsel, that that is a constitutional error that vitiates the appeal?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did you not tell us also that in your opinion the -- the court was responsible to some extent for him not having this appeal because the prisoner informed the court that his counsel was not assisting him and that in spite of that, the court without more decided the case summarily without any review or any investigation --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- of any kind?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That's right Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that's the state action, I assume that you --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Oh, that's -- that is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that you would rely on in coming to a conclusion that he'd either not have due process or he'd not have equal protection of the laws.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: And that's correct.
I think that's a more expressly spelled out in Mr. Belin's brief, but on the facts of this case, we do have a mixture of both of these things.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But it was the ultimate action of the Supreme Court of Iowa which cutoff this man's right to a meaningful appeal.

That is the action of the Supreme Court of Iowa, deprived the man to the help of counsel in arguing an appeal or in briefing an appeal, or in sync to it, that the Supreme Court of Iowa had a full record before it and that ultimately was the action of the Supreme Court of Iowa that resulted in the -- in those deprivals, isn't that right or deprivations, I think?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, I don't think any action that -- I don't believe that the Supreme Court itself deprived the man of counsel in a meaningful sense because counsel had been appointed in the trial court but --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I know, but they – and they knew that and they knew that the man wanted a plenary review and argument of the full record and knowing that and I'm not describing or attributing any fault, but is the way it worked.
This was all before the Court and with that all before the Court, the Court decided his case on this clerk's record without any argument or without any briefing?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And thereby, deprived him of the other meaningful appeal on this --

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: And without any --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- on that state actions, isn't it?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, actually this may not raise a problem of a distinction between situation in which there's appointed counsel and the situation which there's a retained counsel, because I assume that if something of the same sort had happened and a defendant had -- an appellant had told that Iowa's Supreme Court that he had retained the counsel, but that for some reason, retained counsel was not prosecuting his appeal.
The Iowa Supreme Court would take whatever action was appropriate in the circumstances to see that the man's appeal was not defeated?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: If -- if it were not possible for the -- in this situation Mr. Justice Fortas, if it were not possible for the defendant to retain further counsel, the Court would see that counsel was appointed -

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Good point.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: -- to represent him.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: And this happens all the time.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And equal protection doesn't relate exclusively to wealth and poverty and has a broader coverage that that, doesn't it as Mr. Justice Fortas suggests?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Yes, I believe so.
Well, I'd like to -- since Mr. Belin has pressed the merits of the search and seizure and self-incrimination argument, I'd like to take just a few seconds to explain to the Court why --

turn.speaker: justice_bernnan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Bernnan
turn.text: [Inaudible] do you think we're going to have to [Inaudible] than that?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, I don't think so.

turn.speaker: justice_bernnan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Bernnan
turn.text: That was what Mr. Belin raised but I wondered the why we have to spend time on it?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Alright I --

turn.speaker: justice_bernnan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Bernnan
turn.text: Those -- those issues aren't here, are they?

turn.speaker: don_r_bennett
turn.label: Mr. Don R. Bennett
turn.text: Well, Mr. Belin thinks they are.
He expressed them.

Apparently, the merits were pressed in Douglas versus California as I recall I believe Mr. Justice Clark and Mr. Justice Harlan's dissenting opinion and one of the footnotes indicates that they were pressing the merits on this Court in Douglas versus California and the Court didn't decide them.

But I would say this, you've got a copy of the trial transcript up here and you don't have to read it too carefully to find out there is some real difficult question on whether a man consented to these -- to the use of these papers or whether within Schmerber versus California, he hasn't waived any -- waived any argument on the merits of search and seizure and self-incrimination argument because of his failure to raise timely objections.
If there are no further questions, thank you Your Honors.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Belin.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: I'd like to make two comments if I may, first with regard to the merits of the case.
I think it's the duty of all appointed counsel to raise every possible issue for submission to this Court.

And to the extent that I feel that there are substantial errors in the merits, I've done this, number one for the inherent issues themselves and number two, to show the failures of the clerk's transcript system which wouldn't disclose any of these errors whether its appointed counsel or whether it's retained counsel or anything else and I think the inherent defect of the clerk's transcript system --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It also bears -- it also bears on whether or not the counsel made any -- actually decided [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, that's the very point Your Honor.
The -- the fact that with these issues, there was no substantive appeal even assuming that the counsel would have been a retained counsel.
I think, it creates the issues of equal protection and also the question about effective assistance of counsel.

And that's why I've urged that the system itself of a clerk's transcript appeal where there was no record on appeal in the true sense of the word and of course the fact that there's never been a reversal, I think is indicative of the kind of practical operation this system has that there is not been a reversal of a clerk's transcript appeal at least in the 15 years that I know of.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Belin, what if there are two cases before the Iowa Supreme Court exactly like this one where the exactly the same thing happened and one of the case the counsel was appointed and in the other case, the counsel was retained? Exactly the same thing [Inaudible] in this case, do you think it will have the identical results?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Your Honor, my personal belief is it there should be because I don't think that there has been in the one appeal that the defendant has as a matter of right.
If there is negligence on retained counsel, or negligence on appointed counsel, I don't think that you can say that this constitutes an appeal.
And as a matter of fact --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What's the deprivation, [Inaudible] deprivation as to both of these --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: I would say effective assistance of counsel in both situations.
And I think you know --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What would be the ineffective assistance of counsel?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: No presentation of either a record or a brief -- or brief in arguments, so that the court itself --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Failing to file -- failing to file a proper bill of exceptions or what have you told us?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Failure to file a record, fail to file a brief in argument while knowingly, in a state procedure that it really be -- it's the state procedure itself that permits this thing to happen.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what's the -- what's the state charge if anything in an appointed counsel situation?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: In the appointed counsel --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I mean in the -- in the retained counsel?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: In the retained counsel there is a question of state action.
I don't know if you could or could not charge it.
You can have state action where the state appoints a counsel, and particularly in this case where the state was aware for this petition for certiorari.
I think there is a serious constitutional question as to whether you can charge the state with state action where it retained counsel.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There would be the same with the retained counsel?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If the same thing happened with the retained counsel, it would be the same for –

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: If -- if the -- if the state were aware of the fact ahead of time as it was in this case because the petition for certiorari, if you remove -- I mean the petition of certiorari to the Iowa Supreme Court where Mr. Enstminger –-

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you call that a --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you call that a constitutional defect that the counsel didn't file a paper?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, I don't think the counsel -- the fact that the counsel doesn't file a paper makes it a constitutional defect.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Maybe it's one that has to be filed in order to get the appeal?
The civil rules are upheld, just absolutely upheld with provision that the failure to appoint – file papers to the civil court, the lawyer's case can be dismissed by the judge.

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.
And as a matter of fact, it could have been -- it could have happened here.

But at least, if that would have happened, you wouldn't not have had a formal opinion of the Supreme Court affirming the conviction and I think the fatal defect of the clerk's transcript system is that instead of dismissing it which I think they could do if they were to dismiss it what they do is that they affirm they wouldn't appeal the man has as a matter of right under -- under the period -- the one paragraph, one paragraph per curium opinion says based on the record, we have before us, we find no error.
In other words, that's the way the opinion was in this case.
And my position is that the clerk's transcript system doesn't permit a record.
This as Justice Stewart says that theoretically, it's possible to have an error shown so far as instructions are concerned, but in practice, it just doesn't work that way.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I'm looking at -- through the statement of -- the statement of facts in your brief and I thought I'd seen that -- that Mr. Enstminger himself had written to the Supreme Court, well, I don't see that.
I don't find --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Well, yes -- yes, Your Honor.
You can find the actual petition for writ of certiorari on page 27 that Mr. Enstminger wrote of the record on the ground --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: 27 of the record

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: -- record, yes, Your Honor.
And you see he knows how he was charged with the crime and he makes the claim with regard to the use of his papers.
And Mr. Enstminger then points out the appointment of the attorney and on page 28 of record, you can see that Mr. Enstminger assumes that there was a record filed but no brief.
What Mr. Enstminger didn't know when he did that is that there was no record filed --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.
And this -- and this was dated --

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: That was --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's dated -- it's dated October 8th, 1965?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes, and the opinion --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where did that fall in the chronology?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Well, the -- the dismissal of the petition for writ was on October 18 and the opinion was on October 19th.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: About 10 days after?

turn.speaker: david_w_belin
turn.label: Mr. David W. Belin
turn.text: Yes sir.

By the way in the record, I might say there is a typographical error in the record that shows in the record itself, I think in one portion of the opinion was on October 10th, actually it's on October 19th -- and I think in our brief and in the brief of the Attorney General that shows October 19th.
